body:
Let's make this high priority but not blocker: that should be reserved truly for things we can't reasonably release without.  If we mark too many things as 'blocker', we'll simply not be able to manage them, and I don't think this rises to that level (if nothing else, b/c we've been OK since 0.12 was released with this issue).

As a general rule, something that's an enhancement shouldn't be considered a blocker (though as always, exceptions may occur to that rule).

Hands up, it was me setting the priority. I feel that if we're overwriting data without any warning, that's pretty serious. Especially in concert with #1593, which can 'rename' a notebook file without the user intending to.

OK, understood. I guess the question is: if everything was otherwise perfectly ready for release, should we truly block on this alone?  I'm not quite sure it rises to that threshold, but I'm happy to reconsider.

Feel free to bump it again, we can always re-triage as the release time comes to a head.  And we always do, simply out of a need to actually release...
I'll leave this one, but I'll raise #1593 from medium to high, as I think this makes resolving that more pressing.
sounds good, thanks

Right now, the `NotebookManager` has some serious problems:
- It makes no checks to see if it is about to overwrite an existing file.
- It doesn't report errors back to the user in a meaningful way.
- It doesn't check the filename constraints that the JavaScript code enforces.

Because all of these issues are in the same part of the code, they should be fixed with this issue.

The time window for releasing 0.13 is closing in, any realistic chance of progress on this, is it OK to bump it to later, or do we need to block release on it?  My personal take is to just bump it to the 0.14 timeframe.
+1 to bump to 0.14
OK, done. Thanks!

I wish to work on this bug, I plan to do this by appending a time stamp to the older file
<file-name><.SavedAt><timestamp> 
It will give the user a choice to return to previous versions of the file also
So is it possible that the bug can be assigned to me?

> So is it possible that the bug can be assigned to me?

@priyanksh, you don't need to be assigned to work on it ( and actually we can only assign member of the core team).

Just send us a PR that fixes the bug if you whish to.

As I see that you new to github, this means creating a banch that fixes the bug, pushing it to github and clicking the "pull request" button.

By saying "fixes #1702" into your commit message, it will automatically reference this issue when you open a PR.

> I wish to work on this bug, I plan to do this by appending a time stamp to the older file
> <.SavedAt>
> It will give the user a choice to return to previous versions of the file also

As for the way of fixing it. I suggest you read the recent exchange on the ML, as some other users are interested in reworking the backend/frontend. (@benjiec if my memory is correct, sorry otherwise) 

In short, we plan on adding git backend, and need also a UI for that. 

Adding timestamp is IMHO a workaround not a real fix. 
correct fix would be to warn the user and prompt them for a new file name or confirm the overwrite.

Don't hesitate if you have questions.

I am planning to append the UI with the functionality to detect an Overwrite case and ask the user for the following :

-Overwrite 
-RenameExistingFile 
-Cancel (returns to the UI widget that asks for a new name)

RenameExistingFile will save the existing file with a timestamp 

please let me know if i am missing something
I have resolved the above issue on my forked repo, can someone guide me how to append/ verify from you

@priyanksh 

It would be better to push on a named branch instead of master. 
assuming `origin` point to `https://github.com/ipython/ipython`
and `mygithub` to `https://github.com/priyanksh /ipython` :

locally create another branch, swithch to it.

```
$ git branch warn_on_existing_name
$ git checkout warn_on_existing_name
Switched to branch 'warn_on_existing_name'
```

push it to github 

```
$ git push mygithub warn_on_existing_name:warn_on_existing_name                                                                                                            
Counting objects: 40, done.
Delta compression using up to 8 threads.
Compressing objects: 100% (12/12), done.
Writing objects: 100% (36/36), 3.96 KiB, done.
Total 36 (delta 29), reused 29 (delta 24)
To ssh://github/priyanksh/ipython.git
 * [new branch]      warn_on_existing_name -> warn_on_existing_name
```

open https://github/yourname/ipython/ in a new browser
- if you just pushed, github might already tell you 
  `Your recently pushed branches:` `[Pull Request] [Compare] warn_on_existing_name`, then click on Pull Request
- otherwise in the branch menu, select the correct branch, and push `pull request` on the upper right corner.

You'll be guided after, and we'll discuss the rest in the opened PR (**P**ull **R**equest)

I advise you to look at [github help on PR](https://help.github.com/articles/using-pull-requests), with nice screenshot.

And [github help](https://help.github.com/) in general.

Hi, I think there are some a few things we need to work out here.
- First, if a file name is already taken, the user should be be forced to
  change the name of the _newly_ saved/renamed file, not the existing one.
  That is the standard approach in filesystems.
- Second, we need to work out how the AJAX calls are going to be made.  The
  simplest way is to have the save AJAX query return a JSON structure giving
  the information about the status of the filesave.  The client can then look
  at this JSON struct and prompt the user as needed.
- Do we even allow the overwrite option?  I would say that we should not -
  file systems don't allow this.

> RenameExistingFile will save the existing file with a timestamp
> 
> please let me know if i am missing something
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1702#issuecomment-8118828.

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

Also, I don't think the timestamp will be needed to implement this.

I am giving him an option to rename the existing one, but in case he does not wish to, he can choose cancel and give a new name, as he will be redirected to the rename widget

For overwriting and new name, existing save calls are being used, where as i have implemented handler for renaming the existing one and also the function for it

For checking the overwrite on the client side i use a GET request to server to obtain the list of notebooks in the directory and then check for existence.

Is there anything else to be checked / implemented?

Sorry that I can't reply in more depth at this point.

I think the approach you are describing is to complex.

Sent from my iPad

On Aug 29, 2012, at 9:06 PM, priyanksh notifications@github.com wrote:

> I am giving him an option to rename the existing one, but in case he does not wish to, he can choose cancel and give a new name, as he will be redirected to the rename widget
> 
> I think we should only give the user the option to rename the new file, not the original.  There is freedom in simplicity.
> For overwriting and new name, existing save calls are being used, where as i have implemented handler for renaming the existing one and also the function for it
> 
> There are two aspect of this issue that are being confused.  The first is how the server handles overwriting on saves or renames.  It simply should not ever allow that as the potential for data loss is too great.  So let's start there and make sure that overwrites are never possible on the server side of things.  When an overwrite is attempted the server should return a json strict with details about the error.  We need to design this json.  Remember there could be other clients that talk to the server and we have to make sure that those other clients can't overwrite.
> For checking the overwrite on the client side i use a GET request to server to obtain the list of notebooks in the directory and then check for existence.
> 
> It doesn't make sense to do a second GET on each save.  If we solve the problem in the server as I describe above it is not needed.
> Is there anything else to be checked / implemented?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
This work was started in #2360.  This PR was closed because of inactivity, but could be reopened if work continues.
Work has begun on this issue in the closed PR #2768 We have closed it due to inactivity. This issue should be used to track progress and we can reopen the PR if work restarts there.
Is someone planning on starting a PR specifically for this? If not, I think the problem will be fixed in the multi-directory support [PR #3619.](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/3619)

We should just fix this in the multidir PR.

This was started in #4603, but that has been closed due to inactivity. If anyone starts to work on this again, that or another PR can be opened.

I see that this issue is still open, but wondering if there is any way to recover a notebook that was accidentally overwritten by renaming another notebook.  Using Ipython v 1.2.1.  Thanks for your help.
upload confirms overwrite, and rename fails with 409
